review.title: Word2Vec vs DBnary: Augmenting METEOR using Vector Representations or Lexical Resources?
review.abstract: This paper presents an approach combining lexico-semantic resources and distributed representations of words applied to the evaluation in machine translation (MT). This study is made through the enrichment of a well-known MT evaluation metric: METEOR. This metric enables an approximate match (synonymy or morphological similarity) between an automatic and a reference translation. Our experiments are made in the framework of the Metrics task of WMT 2014. We show that distributed representations are a good alternative to lexico-semantic resources for MT evaluation and they can even bring interesting additional information. The augmented versions of METEOR, using vector representations, are made available on our Github page.

sections.heading: 2.1 An automatic metric for MT evaluation: METEOR
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1.1 The origins
sections.text: METEOR was proposed to compensate for the weaknesses of BLEU and NIST (Papineni et al., 2002; Doddington, 2002). In short, METEOR was created to better correlate with human judgments by using more than just word-to-word alignments between a hypothesis and some references.The alignment is based on three modules: the first stage uses an exact match between word surface shapes (Exact Module), the second compares stems (Stem Module) and the third uses synonyms (Synonym Module) from a lexical resource such as WordNet (which is only available in METEOR for English).One contribution of this paper is to propose an alternative to stems and synonym modules: our proposed one will later be called vector module.

sections.heading: 2.1.2 Recent extensions of METEOR
sections.text: METEOR-NEXT (Denkowski and Lavie, 2010a) has been proposed to better correlate with HTER (Humanargeted Translation Edit Rate - HTER (Snover et al., 2006). HTER is a semi-automatic metric based on post-processing that measures the processing distance between a hypothesis and a reference. METEOR-NEXT proposes to go beyond mere word-to-word alignment by using phrase-to-phrase alignments, using phrase databases for different languages such as English (Snover et al., 2009), German, French or Czech (Denkowski and Lavie, 2010b). In a newer version called METEOR Universal, bitextes have been used to extract transcriptions (Denkowski and Lavie, 2014). METEOR has also been added Word Sense Marie (2014) and French language (SD) by the authors.

sections.heading: 2.2 Lexical resources

sections.heading: 2.2.1 WordNet
sections.text: WordNet is a well-known lexical resource for English. Developed at Princeton University (Fellbaum, 1998), it is used in various NLP tasks such as machine translation, Word Sense Disam-3https: / / github.com / cservan / METEOR-Ebiguation, Cross-lingual Information Retrieval, etc. WordNet links nouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs with a series of synonyms called "synsets." Each synthesis represents a specific concept. Synsets are linked to each other by semantic, conceptual, and lexical relationships. Words with multiple meanings correspond to multiple synsets and meanings are sorted according to their frequency. WordNet is available in several languages (Arabic, French, etc.), but these versions are not freely available. In METEOR, only English WordNet is used to match hypotheses and their meanings.

sections.heading: 2.2.2 DBnary
sections.text: DBnary is a multilingual lexical resource in RDF format (Klyne and Carroll, 2004), collected by Sérasset (2012). Dictionary data is presented using the LEMON vocabulary (McCrae et al., 2011), making it reusable in many contexts. DBnary is downloadable from a SPARQL access point or available online. DBnary data is automatically extracted from Wiktionary, the Wikipedia dictionary for 21 languages. [4] Among the available lexical data, there are 2.9M lexical entries (with parts of the language, canonical forms for all of them, along with pronunciations when available and inflated forms for some languages.] DBnary entries are divided into 2.5 M lexical entries (with parts of the language, canonical form for all of them, along with pronunciations, if available, and inflated forms for some languages).

sections.heading: 2.3 Monolingual and bilingual embeddings
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.3.1 Overview
sections.text: Learning word embedding is an active field of research (Bengio et al., 2003; Turian et al., 2010; Collobert et al., 2011; Huang et al., 2012).The basic idea is to learn word representation according to its context: the surrounding words (Baroni and Zamparelli, 2010).The words are projected onto a continuous space and those with a similar context should be close in this multidimensional space. If word vectors are available, a similarity between two words can be measured using a metric such as a cosmic similarity. The use of word embedding for machine translation evaluation is appealing as it can be used to calculate similarities between words or phrases in the same language (monolingual embedding capture synonymic or morphological proximity) or in two different languages (bilingual embedding allows direct calculation between words or phrases in the same language).

sections.heading: 4.3 Discussion
sections.text: The correlation values obtained with the enriched metric tend to indicate that distributed representations are as powerful as lexical-semantic resources for automatic MT evaluation. In addition, vector representations can provide additional information, and they are definitely useful when no lexical resource is available in the target language. On the other hand, if we combine lexical data with vector module (METEOR DBnary + Vector), we find a small increase in correlation value, especially when adjusting thresholds, which results in a tunable version of METEOR. Finally, several embedding variants have been trained, but it seems that monolingual models are efficient enough for the specific task considered here (MT evaluation).

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Limitations of Word Embeddings
sections.text: By OOV we mean words that do not have vector representation because they have not been found in the training corpus for word embedding. In this case, there can be no correspondence between the word in the hypothesis and the words in the reference. Consequently, it might be interesting to carefully select the training corpus for word vectors so that it is close enough to the results of machine translation to evaluate them. This could be taken into account in future work.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Perspectives
sections.text: Our work has been applied to the evaluation of machine translations and we have expanded an existing evaluation metric called METEOR. Our experiments have shown that word vector representations can be useful when there are no lexical resources available in the target language. Furthermore, it seems that these representations can provide additional information in addition to lexical resources (experiments being carried out for French, English, German and Russian as target languages).Our future work on this topic will focus on the use of phrase embeddings to supplement the METEOR paraphrase module. We also plan to introduce a syntax variant in our vector module by weighting cosmic distances differently according to the morphosyntactic category of words. Finally, we will examine the adaptation of our approach to other metrics such as TER-Plus to enable instance.The tool, data and models in this paper will be presented on the basis of 8 repeat lines.
